dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, welcome back, folks! Q1, uh, was quite the ride, wasn't it? I mean, we saw some *massive* volatility in the markets.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, welcome back, folks! Q one, uh, was quite the ride, wasn't it? I mean, we saw some massive volatility in the markets.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Meme stocks such as GameStop experienced massive volatility over the last quarter.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. And I think the biggest headline, like, right off the bat, has to be those meme stocks. GameStop, AMC... just *wild*.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. And I think the biggest headline, like, right off the bat, has to be those meme stocks. GameStop, A M C... just wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Meme stocks such as GameStop experienced massive volatility over the last quarter. ... Stocks such as AMC, American Airlines, PLTR, AMD and NIO moved significantly higher, but some of them lost their steam.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wild is an understatement. I mean, we're talking about retail investors really giving, uh, hedge funds a serious "nose bleed," as they say. [interrupts] Taking completely opposite bets.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wild is an understatement. I mean, we're talking about retail investors really giving, uh, hedge funds a serious nose bleed, as they say. Taking completely opposite bets.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Retail investors gave severe nose bleeds to hedge funds which built short positions in GameStop. A lot of this was chiefly due to the fact that retail traders took opposite bets against hedge funds.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly! And it's like, the so-called "smart money" can't ignore these retail traders anymore. PLTR, AMD, NIO, they all got a boost from it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly! And it's like, the so-called smart money can't ignore these retail traders anymore. P L T R, A M D, N I O, they all got a boost from it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The so called-smart money institutions and money managers can no longer ignore retail traders. Stocks such as AMC, American Airlines, PLTR, AMD and NIO moved significantly higher, but some of them lost their steam.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right. And then, changing gears a bit, another *huge* theme that I think everyone was talking about was Tesla and Bitcoin.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. And then, changing gears a bit, another huge theme that I think everyone was talking about was Tesla and Bitcoin.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Tesla And Bitcoin Another major theme during the first quarter, and possibly the biggest event, was Tesla's investment in Bitcoin.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, definitely. Tesla's investment really opened up this whole conversation, you know, about other S&P 500 companies maybe diversifying their treasury with crypto. Even if Tesla's a bit unique.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, definitely. Tesla's investment really opened up this whole conversation, you know, about other S and P five hundred companies maybe diversifying their treasury with crypto. Even if Tesla's a bit unique.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This has opened the conversation that other S&P 500 companies could also diversify their treasury system by allocating some portion of their capital in Bitcoin. Of course, Tesla is one-of-a-kind.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. And speaking of new ways to invest, SPACs, or blank-check companies, just exploded in popularity. Celebrities backing them, sports personalities...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. And speaking of new ways to invest, S P A C s, or blank-check companies, just exploded in popularity. Celebrities backing them, sports personalities...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Special Purpose Acquisition Companies (SPACs), also known as blank-check companies, became increasingly popular during the first quarter of 2021. We have had 250+ SPACs so far this year, and celebrities and sports personalities are backing them up as sponsors.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like, Cathie Wood even got involved in one with Serena Williams on the board! It was everywhere.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like, Cathie Wood even got involved in one with Serena Williams on the board! It was everywhere.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Investors like Cathie Wood, from ARK Investment Management LLC, also bought a SPAC with tennis star Serena Williams on the board.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. Now, on the other side of things, we also saw a pretty significant sector rotation, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. Now, on the other side of things, we also saw a pretty significant sector rotation, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Sector Rotation Soaring Treasury yields and concerns about rising inflation made investors sell tech stocks during the first quarter.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, with those soaring Treasury yields and inflation concerns, a lot of investors were, um, selling off tech stocks. The Nasdaq really lagged compared to the S&P and Dow.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, with those soaring Treasury yields and inflation concerns, a lot of investors were, um, selling off tech stocks. The Nasdaq really lagged compared to the S and P and Dow.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Soaring Treasury yields and concerns about rising inflation made investors sell tech stocks during the first quarter. The Nasdaq Composite index is certainly the laggard among the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones Industrial Average.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Which meant money was flowing into, like, cyclical and value stocks for Q1.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which meant money was flowing into, like, cyclical and value stocks for Q one.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We have seen money flowing into cyclical and value stocks during the first quarter.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And then, we can't forget Archegos Capital Management. That was a *huge* story.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And then, we can't forget Archegos Capital Management. That was a huge story.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Archegos Capital Management The Security Exchange Commission (SEC) isn't only concerned about leverage-related issues concerning retail traders. Archegos Capital Management was given excessive leverage by major banks such as Credit Suisse, Deutsche Bank and many more.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, man. The SEC isn't just worried about retail leverage anymore. This was, uh, a major family office getting massive leverage from big banks like Credit Suisse.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, man. The S E C isn't just worried about retail leverage anymore. This was, uh, a major family office getting massive leverage from big banks like Credit Suisse.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Security Exchange Commission (SEC) isn't only concerned about leverage-related issues concerning retail traders. Archegos Capital Management was given excessive leverage by major banks such as Credit Suisse, Deutsche Bank and many more.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and then they were forced to sell off those tech positions, and it caused shares of companies like ViacomCBS to just *plunge*. Banks like Credit Suisse even issued profit warnings.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and then they were forced to sell off those tech positions, and it caused shares of companies like ViacomC B S to just plunge. Banks like Credit Suisse even issued profit warnings.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The family office was forced to sell its tech positions in media companies such as Tencent Music, ViacomCBS, Discovery and Baidu. Shares of these companies plunged, and this also made banks like Credit Suisse issue grave profit warnings.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, looking forward, it feels like this battle, this new dynamic, is just gonna continue. We've got more stimulus, right? Biden signed that $1.9 trillion package.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, looking forward, it feels like this battle, this new dynamic, is just gonna continue. We've got more stimulus, right? Biden signed that one point nine trillion dollar package.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: U.S. President Joe Biden signed another coronavirus-related stimulus package of $1.9 trillion, which has armed traders with fresh capital.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, fresh capital for traders, and some estimates are saying nearly $190 billion of that could boost the stock market. It's clear that retail money, uh, can't be discounted.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, fresh capital for traders, and some estimates are saying nearly one hundred ninety billion dollars of that could boost the stock market. It's clear that retail money, uh, can't be discounted.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It has been stated that nearly $190 billion of the stimulus money could boost the stock market. ... The key point to keep in mind is that we can no longer discount the strength of retail money.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right. And with Wallstreetbets and those social forums, they've got money, and they're gonna put it somewhere. Plus, the SEC is probably gonna get tougher on family offices to prevent another Archegos situation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. And with Wallstreetbets and those social forums, they've got money, and they're gonna put it somewhere. Plus, the S E C is probably gonna get tougher on family offices to prevent another Archegos situation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We may likely see the social forums such as Wallstreetbets picking up momentum. After all, retail traders do have money, and they will invest it somewhere. Regulations The SEC is likely to adopt a tougher stance on family offices to avoid any systematic risk to the financial system.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And then just yesterday, Biden announced his *new* infrastructure stimulus plan, another $2 trillion. Even with Congress, you know, it's a narrow majority, but lawmakers know we need those upgrades.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And then just yesterday, Biden announced his new infrastructure stimulus plan, another two trillion dollars. Even with Congress, you know, it's a narrow majority, but lawmakers know we need those upgrades.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: President Biden revealed his new infrastructure stimulus plan of $2 trillion yesterday. Although Democrats control both chambers of Congress, their majority is only by a narrow margin. So, it is essential to keep in mind that while Democrats may support all the infrastructure spending such as building new bridges, airports and upgrading the internet infrastructure, Republicans aren't likely to nod their heads for a tax hike.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, more money, more stimulus, and, uh, the markets seem pretty addicted to that news. It's going to be an interesting next few months, for sure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, more money, more stimulus, and, uh, the markets seem pretty addicted to that news. It's going to be an interesting next few months, for sure.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As for the market, traders are addicted to stimulus-related news, resulting in markets moving much higher.
